class_notes:
This course examines the history of Native peoples in North America before 1900. Integrating the materials and methods of Native American and Indigenous Studies, the class takes an interdisciplinary approach to the past and considers themes such as resistance to colonialism, maintenance of political sovereignty, and adaptation to cultural change. 
Because Emory University occupies Muscogee (Creek) land, this course grounds its panoramic investigation of diverse yet interconnected Native American histories with a special focus on the Indigenous peoples who lived, worked, produced knowledge on, and nurtured the land where the university's Oxford and Atlanta campuses are now located. Course lectures, assigned media, primary sources, class discussions, and experiential learning opportunities develop both foundational knowledge of Native North American history while also contributing to campuswide efforts to (re)establish meaningful and improved relations with Southeastern tribal nations.


Instructor is Prof. Michael Mortimer, Postdoctoral Fellow in Native North American History.
